newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Foreign troops may stay in Albania to September.
newsitem.headline: Foreign troops may stay in Albania to September.

text.p: International troops safeguarding security in Albania ahead of elections at the end of June could stay on until September, a spokesman for the Italian-led force said on Saturday.
Albanian television said the national unity government had agreed to ask the international community to extend the force's mandate by three months from June 28.
"It is obvious that the mandate will be extended,", said the spokesman, Lieutenant-Colonel Giovanni Bernardi, but for how long was not yet clear.
The force, made up of troops from 10 European countries, had been due to move out on the day before the first round of polling.
Its mandate was set by the United Nations Security Council, but a Rome-based steering committee of all the participating countries may make a recommendation on its extension, Bernardi said.
Albanians are to vote in early parliamentary elections on June 29 after months of disruption triggered by the collapse of fraudulent savings schemes early this year.
Tension have been mounting as polling day approaches. Incidents this week included a failed attempt on the life of President Sali Berisha at an election rally.

The interim nine-party government of Socialist Prime Minister Bashkim Fino, formed in March to guide the country to elections, plans to step up security during the campaigning period, the television said.
